title: Srimad Bhagavatam | Sri Mahotsaha Chaitanya Dasa | SB 1.19.1 | 17.11.2024
speaker: HG Amitasana Dasa

segments.key_quote: A pious king regretted his accidental improper treatment of the powerful brahmana who was faultless.
segments.summary: The speaker begins by reading from Srimad Bhagavatam and discusses the importance of repentance for accidental sins committed by devotees.

segments.key_quote: So the nature of Kali Yuga is, the Kali Yuga is even famous as the age of quarrel.
segments.summary: The speaker transitions to discussing current events, specifically a cricket tournament controversy, to illustrate the quarrelsome nature of Kali Yuga and how it manifests at various levels of society.

segments.key_quote: Yet, Srimad Bhagavatam, by its existence, exemplary devotees, narrations of the exemplary devotees, has given us practical demonstration of how we can live peacefully in this world, even in the current age of Kali, if we practice the principles mentioned in Srimad Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The speaker highlights ISKCON as an example of how people from diverse backgrounds can unite through Krishna consciousness and live peacefully despite the challenges of Kali Yuga.

segments.key_quote: The international society for Krishna consciousness has been organized for this purpose.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the purpose of ISKCON, citing a verse from Srimad Bhagavatam, emphasizing the importance of devotee association for understanding the Lord and His devotees.

segments.key_quote: Anyone can join the international society for Krishna consciousness and be initiated to become twice born.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the opportunity for anyone to join ISKCON, become initiated, and be considered twice-born, emphasizing that advancement in devotional service is only possible in the association of devotees.

segments.key_quote: ISKCON is a hospital.
segments.summary: The speaker acknowledges that friction and disagreements are natural when living with others, even in ISKCON, and uses the analogy of ISKCON being a hospital for those who recognize their spiritual disease.

segments.key_quote: Those who don't come to ISKCON, they don't know that they are deceased.
segments.summary: The speaker continues the hospital analogy, explaining that those who come to ISKCON are aware of their spiritual disease and are seeking treatment, and that devotional service makes the material world appear full of pleasure.

segments.key_quote: By devotional service one is elevated to transcendental planet Goloka and Dhavan and also there, there is only devotional service.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that devotional service is the same in both the material and spiritual worlds, using the analogy of an unripe and ripe mango to illustrate the difference in relishability.

segments.key_quote: Therefore, it is possible to mature in devotional service only in the association of devotees.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of devotee association for maturing in devotional service, comparing devotees to unripe mangoes that may taste sour but can grow together in ISKCON.

segments.key_quote: All devotees dark ugly put together nice rubbing and after that shiny diamond like pure devotees will come that is the formula of getting together devotees in ISKCON
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of diamonds being polished through friction to illustrate how devotees, through association and interaction, can become more refined and pure.

segments.key_quote: You have come to the association of devotees for the disconnected with the philosophy with the process of life not for not connected with this man or that man.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces a quote from a Bhagavad Gita lecture by Srila Prabhupada, using the analogy of a ship journey to emphasize the importance of tolerance and focusing on the philosophy rather than the personalities of fellow devotees.

segments.key_quote: You have to be tolerant sit tight sit down tightly on the ship and take advantage of the opportunity
segments.summary: The speaker continues to elaborate on the ship analogy, stressing the need for tolerance and focusing on the opportunity for spiritual advancement rather than being distracted by the imperfections of others.

themes: strict with others, lenient with self
segments.key_quote: Strict with others lenient with self
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the common tendency to be strict with others and lenient with oneself, emphasizing that the purpose of Krishna consciousness is to purify one's conditioning rather than displaying it.

segments.key_quote: So this is the how devotee should feel upon apologetic we should always be careful first of all not to offend and in case we have offended knowingly or unknowingly we should be ready to apologize
segments.summary: The speaker returns to the story of Maharaj Parikshit and Shringi, highlighting their exemplary behavior and the importance of being apologetic and ready to apologize for offenses.

segments.key_quote: Apology is such an important thing when it comes to ourselves because we are lenient to ourselves even if we make a mistake
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of apologizing, even for accidental mistakes, and contrasts it with uncivilized behavior.

segments.key_quote: By saying sorry we will become small less that's what we think
segments.summary: The speaker explores the reasons why it is difficult to apologize, attributing it to ego and the fear of appearing small, and emphasizes the benefits of apologizing for one's own improvement, humility, and peace of mind.

segments.key_quote: To apologize for our own improvement for our own humility for our own peace of mind for our own
segments.summary: The speaker continues to discuss the reasons for apologizing, emphasizing humility and peace, and outlines various situations when one should apologize, even when not at fault.

segments.key_quote: Every day in our morning routine after Mangalarati after Tulsi Puja after circumambulating the Tulsi Maharani circumambulating Tulsi Maharani we say
segments.summary: The speaker describes the daily routine of collective apology practiced by devotees, and identifies who one should apologize to: specific devotees, collectively to all devotees, to the spiritual master, and to the Lord.

segments.key_quote: Real apology means changed behavior
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that a real apology involves changed behavior, and outlines the components of a full apology: acknowledging the mistake, realizing it was wrong, and committing to not repeating it.

segments.key_quote: If you have committed some mistake you have to first repent realize I have made a mistake repent it repent for it
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the formula of RPP (Repent, Pray, Plan) as a framework for dealing with mistakes, emphasizing the importance of repentance, prayer for strength, and planning to avoid repeating the mistake.

segments.key_quote: There is difference between repentance versus guilt what is guilt?
segments.summary: The speaker highlights how Parikshit Maharaj implemented RPP, and distinguishes between guilt (which is passive and unproductive) and repentance (which involves action and planning).

segments.key_quote: Repentance means actual repentance means RPP repentance pray and plan
segments.summary: The speaker further clarifies the difference between guilt and repentance, emphasizing that repentance involves positive action and planning, and that devotees often commit unconscious offenses.

segments.key_quote: First stage of bad habits is when we are in bad habit effortless defeat habit is there we are succumb to that habit
segments.summary: The speaker introduces a pattern for changing habits, outlining the stages of spiritual progress from effortless defeat to effortless victory, and acknowledging the struggles faced by sadhakas.

segments.key_quote: Struggle and victory we will struggle still it is a struggle not the test has gone away for the struggling but we are successful in overcoming
segments.summary: The speaker continues to describe the stages of spiritual progress, from struggle and defeat to struggle and victory, and ultimately to effortless victory, highlighting the challenges and triumphs along the path.

segments.key_quote: What Srimad Bhagavatam is setting is the ideal benchmark
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that the examples in Srimad Bhagavatam are ideals of pure devotees, and that even faultless devotees can be overcome by the will of providence.

segments.key_quote: At all times at least daily as a routine as a practice apologize
segments.summary: The speaker outlines different levels of apology, from daily routine practice to addressing situations where one feels wronged, and emphasizes the importance of fairness and justice.

segments.key_quote: Always in our dealings we think of giving hundred percent from our side in relationship and expect zero percent from the other side
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 100-0 principle, encouraging devotees to give 100% in relationships and expect nothing in return, using the example of saying Hare Krishna and not receiving a response.

segments.key_quote: I say Hare Krishna that devotee didn't respond to Hare Krishna because when I saw that devotee I could remember Krishna and I said Hare Krishna but when he saw I am such a fallen soul he could not remember Krishna by seeing me that's why he didn't say Hare Krishna
segments.summary: The speaker describes how a pure devotee thinks, taking responsibility for another's lack of response to Hare Krishna, and concludes by summarizing the essence of Parikshit Maharaj's teachings.
